original_data.question: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of fever, abdominal pain, and rapidly progressive distension of the abdomen. His appendix was removed for an abscess 3 days ago. The complete blood count showed leukocytosis. Anaerobic culture of the peritoneal fluid needle aspirate showed a gram-negative pathogen. Which of the following, in addition to polymicrobial infection, is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is an anaerobic gram-negative pathogen, Bacteroides fragilis. This organism is the most common anaerobic isolate from intra-abdominal infections. It is part of the normal flora of the colon and is the most common cause of anaerobic infections of the abdomen and pelvis. It is a gram-negative rod that grows under anaerobic conditions. It is part of a mixed growth in which it is often overgrown by facultative bacteria. The other organisms listed are not anaerobes.

Campylobacter jejuni is a gram-negative rod that causes gastroenteritis. It is not an anaerobe. It is part of the normal flora of many domestic animals and is the most common cause of bacterial gastroenteritis in most developed countries.

Clostridium perfringens is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod that causes gastroenteritis and gas gangrene. It is not an anaerobe. It is part of the normal flora of the intestine and can be found in the feces of many healthy individuals.

Shigella sonnei is a gram-negative rod that causes gastroenteritis. It is not an anaerobe. It is part of the normal flora of many developing countries and is the most common cause of bacterial gastroenteritis in some of these countries.

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a gram-negative rod that causes gastroenteritis. It is not an anaerobe. It is part of the normal flora of the ocean and causes infections after the ingestion of raw seafood.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>
